sections.title: What this section covers
sections.content:
**Punctuation** (especially commas) and **capitalisation** in English.

Focus on differences from Czech so you can avoid common mistakes.

• **Check** – test your understanding.
• **Practice** – add or correct punctuation and capitals.

sections.title: Commas – when to use them
sections.content:
Use a comma:

• **In lists** (before 'and' optional in British English): apples, oranges, and bananas.
• **After introductory words or phrases:** However, we agreed. After the meeting, he left.
• **Before but, and, or, so, yet** when they join two full sentences: I called, but she was busy.
• **Around extra (non-defining) information:** My brother, who lives in London, is a doctor.

Do **not** use a comma when the information is essential (defining): The man who called yesterday left a message.

sections.title: Czech vs English – commas
sections.content:
**Differences that often cause mistakes:**

• **Before že (that):** Czech often uses a comma before že. English usually does **not**: I think that he is right. (no comma before 'that' in most cases)

• **Before and/but:** In English we use a comma when and/but joins two **full sentences**: She smiled, and I waved. If you only join two words or short phrases, no comma: She smiled and waved.

• **Lists:** Czech may use a comma where English uses no comma (e.g. before a final item). In British English the last comma (before 'and') is optional.

sections.title: Capitalisation
sections.content:
In English we capitalise:

• **I** (the person) – always: He and I went.
• **First word of a sentence.**
• **Proper nouns:** London, Jan, the European Union.
• **Days and months:** Monday, March. (Czech: pondělí, březen – small letter)
• **Nationalities and languages:** English, Czech, French.
• **Titles of books/films:** (main words) The Lord of the Rings.

Do **not** capitalise general nouns (e.g. 'university' unless part of a name: Oxford University).

sections.title: Czech vs English – capitalisation
sections.content:
**Typical mistakes for Czech learners:**

• **Days and months** – In English always capitalise: **Monday**, **January**. In Czech they are written with a small letter (pondělí, leden).

• **I** – In English **I** is always a capital letter. In Czech 'já' is not capitalised.

• **Nationalities/languages** – English, Czech, German (capital in English).

• **First word after a colon** – In English it depends on style; often capital if a full sentence follows. In Czech often small letter.

sections.title: Quick summary
sections.content:
• **Commas:** lists, after introductory phrases, before but/and when joining two sentences, around non-defining clauses. Not before 'that' (I think that…).
• **Capitalise:** I, first word of sentence, proper nouns, days, months, nationalities, languages.
• Don't transfer Czech comma or capitalisation rules – follow English rules.

questions.question: Which is correct?

options.a: I think that he is right.
options.b: I think, that he is right.
options.c: I think that, he is right.
options.d: I think, that, he is right.

questions.explanation: In English we usually do not put a comma before 'that' in this type of sentence (unlike Czech before že).

questions.question: Which is correct?
questions.explanation: Days of the week are capitalised in English (unlike in Czech).

questions.question: Which is correct?
questions.explanation: The pronoun I is always capitalised in English. First word of sentence is capitalised.

questions.question: Which is correct? (You have more than one brother; the London one is the doctor.)

options.a: My brother who lives in London is a doctor.
options.b: My brother, who lives in London, is a doctor.
options.c: My brother, who lives in London is a doctor.
options.d: My brother who lives in London, is a doctor.

questions.explanation: When the clause is extra (non-defining) information, we put commas around it: My brother, who lives in London, is a doctor.

questions.question: Which is correct?
questions.explanation: Languages and nationalities are capitalised in English. Sentence starts with a capital.

questions.question: Wrong: 'I think, that she is coming.' Correct the sentence.
answers: I think that she is coming.
I think that she is coming
questions.explanation: No comma before 'that' in English in this pattern.

questions.question: Wrong: 'we went on monday.' Correct the sentence.
answers: We went on Monday.
We went on Monday
questions.explanation: Capitalise first word of sentence and the day of the week.

questions.question: Wrong: 'He and i left early.' Correct the sentence.
answers: He and I left early.
He and I left early
questions.explanation: The pronoun I is always written with a capital letter in English.

questions.question: Wrong: 'She speaks english and german.' Correct the sentence.
answers: She speaks English and German.
She speaks English and German

questions.question: Wrong: 'I called but she was busy.' (Add a comma where needed.)
answers: I called, but she was busy.
I called, but she was busy
questions.explanation: Use a comma before 'but' when it joins two full sentences.

questions.question: Wrong: 'However we decided to stay.' Correct the sentence.
answers: However, we decided to stay.
However, we decided to stay
questions.explanation: Use a comma after introductory words like However.

questions.question: Wrong: 'In january we went to prague.' Correct the sentence.
answers: In January we went to Prague.
In January we went to Prague
questions.explanation: Capitalise months and place names (proper nouns).

questions.question: Wrong: 'The man, who stole the bag, was caught.' (The clause is essential – there were several men, and we mean the one who stole the bag.) Correct by removing unnecessary commas.
answers: The man who stole the bag was caught.
The man who stole the bag was caught
questions.explanation: No commas when the clause is defining (essential to identify which man).

questions.question: Wrong: 'after the meeting he went home.' Correct the sentence.
answers: After the meeting, he went home.
After the meeting, he went home
questions.explanation: Capitalise first word; comma after introductory phrase 'After the meeting'.

questions.question: Wrong: 'She said that, she would come.' Correct the sentence.
answers: She said that she would come.
She said that she would come
questions.explanation: No comma before or after 'that' in this type of sentence.
